Thank you for your very well detailed explanation regarding Netorare, Mister ChalkIV.
9/10 pretty hot

Thus, Netorare is essentially cuckold as a genre, but taken to an extremely brutal level. It not only induces a depressing message regarding love and trust, but it also murders the male audience's perception toward women and their own masculinity - i.e. someone who cannot satisfy their lover is a loser. And given that the male protagonist is supposed to be a character the average male fan can relate to, the reactions are to be expected.

However, another factor in the hatred of Netorare is the degradation of males' self-esteem. The typical ending to visual novels and hentai is where the male protagonist is left off in his miserable and pathetic state as a lonely virgin while the girl is whisked away having wild sex with one or many men. With the lack of confidence and self-esteem to do anything for their lover, it arouses sexual jealousy from the males, hence the most common phrases or thoughts are "Why won't you do it with me?" or "I'm the one you're supposed to have sex with." It also goes back to the old views of the cuckold - someone who sleeps with another man's love interest will receive massive victory over the man who has been cheated which leaves him humiliated and victimized. While that view is not outright shown nowadays, that stigma is still intact psychologically.

Many female love interests take the form of an ideal woman. They would often be the cute girlfriend, a childhood friend, or a married woman. As explained previously, all of them invoke an aura of their typical womanhood purity, especially in Japan where the traditional view is strong. Seeing them become corrupted and promiscuous invokes the fears into the male audience of women breaking the barrier of their cultural standards.

Why do people hate Netorare? ...and for some, a guilty pleasure? As one might effortlessly predict, many people seriously detest Netorare. It might have to do with the oft-idealized nature of relationships in anime and manga culture, along with the fanbase's obsession with purity — a phenomenon apparent by the popularity of concepts like a teen's first "adult" kiss on the lips being a momentous occasion, or the idea of the traditional Japanese ideal woman: domestic and submissive, but not a pushover. That is to say, fans of Japanese anime and manga seem to have a strong connection with a specific, sugary perception of romantic relationships, built around pure, sincere, genuine commitment. Hence Netorare, leaning closer to the cynical side on the scale of idealism versus cynicism, tends to rub people the wrong way. In spite of all the hate, some people are genuinely attracted to this kind of story, for various reasons.

“Hey, you know what’s a great idea? Introduce a hot girl and a dude who has shadows for eyes and then just out of nowhere forget he exists in favor of an ugly bastard who basically kills any sense of sexiness to this doujin! Wouldn’t that just be fun? I feel like that would be fun.” The dude’s friend sighs and looks at him. “Dude, I think your unhealthy obsession with making your characters and more importantly, your AUDIENCE suffer is getting to you. You haven’t called family in months, your little brother has practically had to grow up knowing he’s never really gonna have much of an older brother, and you can’t hold down a relationship for more than a few months since Sh-…. *sigh* I’m sorry. I just think it’s better if you were to talk to someone, alright man?” The dude’s empty smile lingers, numb to many things now, he just looks down. “… that doesn’t sound too fun.”
